body: For years, commuters between Queens and Manhattan have complained about overcrowded subway trains and long waits on platforms. With the addition today of a new subway line, officials say that these commuters will have an easier ride. The new subway line, called the V train, will make 24 stops between 71st Avenue in Forest Hills, Queens, and Second
title: V Train Begins Service Today, Giving Queens Commuters Another Option

title: After Bus Worker's 11th Injury Claim in 20 Years, He's Arrested

While many people slept undisturbed through the jiggling, some New Yorkers felt their beds
title: Still on Edge, New York Is Rattled By a Quake

body: A picture caption yesterday about the television program ''Third Watch'' misstated the location of the filming of an outdoor scene. It was Vernon Boulevard in Long Island City, Queens, not Greenpoint, Brooklyn.

title: And Now, We Return To Scheduled Programs; TV Production Quickly Rebounds, With New York City as a Backdrop

body: In Fort Greene, Brooklyn, a crew of black and Latino teenage boys say they can no longer think of the police as enemies. Since Sept. 11, the boys say, the officers who patrol their neighborhoods, most of whom are white, no longer eye them with suspicion. title: A NATION CHALLENGED: RELATIONS; Sept. 11 Attack Narrows the Racial Divide

title: Ferrer the Campaigner Offers an Old-Style Approach

title: Council Endorsements: Brooklyn

body: It's official. Brooklyn and Queens have arrived, and they've got their own alternative weekly newspaper to prove it. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; 2 Boroughs Arrive (Once Again) With a New Newspaper's Arrival

title: Urging Students to College By Speeding the Path to It

body: Phantom Railroad Q. On Hancock Street in Bushwick, Brooklyn, there is a railroad crossing sign near Wyckoff Avenue, but I can't see any tracks. Why the sign? A. You need not stop or even slow down; a train hasn't crossed Hancock Street in nearly 40 years. The sign is a remnant of the New York and Manhattan Beach Railway, which was started in 1870
title: F.Y.I.

title: Officer Cleared in Shooting

body: The new Bard High School Early College in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, an effort to let high-achieving public high school students start college two years early, has accepted about 100 students for 9th grade and more than 70 students who have completed 10th grade and now will begin the first year of college. title: BULLETIN BOARD; Applications Open for High Achievers

title: SOAPBOX; The Giants Are Gone

title: TURF; Trading Sweat for Shares

body: AS the September primaries approach, hundreds of attention-starved politicians are working the city like entertainers at an enormous birthday party, making balloon animals in the living room while the children sit in the den, watching Barney. Still, certain surnames get bandied about: Badillo, Bloomberg, Ferrer, Green, Hevesi, Vallone, Skurnik.
title: PUBLIC LIVES; A Diviner of Meaning in Political Names and Lists

body: ON Good Friday, the Rev. Gordon H. Duggins, who seems to perpetually sweat under his heavy black suit and tight clerical collar, preaches the same sermon every year. It is called ''Why Heaven Needs Felons.'' It might elicit grimaces in more well-heeled parishes, but members of his congregation have spent more time behind bars than in church school,
title: PUBLIC LIVES; A Minister Who Appreciates a Good Felon

title: An Arrest in 6 Attacks on Women in Brooklyn

title: Memories Rise As Tanks Fall In Brooklyn

body: A suit seeking to delay the implosion of two 400-foot-high empty natural-gas storage tanks in Greenpoint was rejected by a civil court judge yesterday. The tanks, owned by the KeySpan Energy Corporation, are to be demolished Sunday. The suit, filed yesterday by Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez and community groups, argued that KeySpan had not given proper
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: No Delay To Tanks' Destruction

body: An article on Monday about plans to destroy two natural gas tanks in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, misstated the age of one neighborhood resident, Annette Lamatto. She is 43, not 49.
title: Corrections

body: The toughest crisis I have ever faced was the bombing of the World Trade Center in 1993. Our offices were on the top five floors. Normally I parked in the underground lot where the bomb exploded, but by coincidence, my car was in the shop that day so I rode with someone else. I arrived around noon, sat down to a lunch meeting at 12:15, and the bomb
title: THE BOSS; Keeping the Band Together

body: It won't be long now. The explosives arrived on Friday. At 7 a.m. Sunday, while most of the city sleeps, two mammoth natural-gas storage tanks that have defined the landscape of northern Brooklyn for decades will fall with a shudder and a boom, and with them a big chunk of New York's industrial history. When they were built by the Brooklyn Union
title: Last Days for Brooklyn's Giants; Twin Tanks Carry a Love-Hate Reputation to the End

body: LAST Fourth of July, the day throngs of spectators flocked to the New York waterfront to watch giant ships glide in from around the world, 200 white-clad sailors and 400 civilians caroused on the roof of a building in the Brooklyn Navy Yard overlooking the docks. title: Yard Work

title: For Class of 2001, a Less Frenetic Market

body: With warm weather, so many things return to New York: the tourists to the subways, the fans to the baseball stadiums, the blue crabs to the Hudson. But the warmth brings back something else, a lot more technical, a lot less welcome and yet just as inseparable from summer in the city: the perfect temperatures for freshly poured concrete and asphalt
title: You Can't Get There From Here: Summer Brings Lots More Road Work; Cabbies Sigh as Workers in Trenches Dig, Repair and Repave

body: Sam Chwat, the dean of New York chat, roams the streets as a giant ear would, listening. A coach to Midwesterners, Southerners and other regional imports who want to talk New York for Broadway and film, he needs to hear, and often tape-record, the contours of each local accent, from Rosie Perez to Fran Drescher. ''My ears are always on duty,'' he
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK FOLKLORE; A Teacher of Newyorkese Who Taps the Power of Babel

body: With eight million people to pick from, Nancy Groce winnowed it down to 200. She lined up Andrew Rosenwach to handle the water tower. She picked out Steve Ross to make the bagels. She wanted a bus driver, and she figured, how can you go wrong with Tony Palombella? He works the 96th Street crosstown route, loves to joke around, tell stories. She got
title: Graffiti Artists and Bialy Makers; The Smithsonian Gathers a Few of New York's Unsung

body: The Board of Education is creating a joint program with Bard College that will allow select 11th graders to start college at a special institute in Brooklyn. Accepted students will forgo high school diplomas, instead effectively getting two free years of college during what would have been the 11th and 12th grades. They will take accelerated
title: Program to Provide a Head Start on College

body: After commuters and Governor Pataki protested proposed cuts in G train service, New York Transit voted Thursday to revise the plan. G service will be unchanged on evenings and weekends. But on weekdays it will still terminate at Court Square to make room for a new V train, and the number of cars on G trains will be reduced to four from six. But
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN -- UPDATES; Take the G Train? Official Revision

author: E-mail: daschn@nytimes.com
body: The Rare Bloodroot Q.: Centuries ago, the native inhabitants here used the juice of the bloodroot flower to make dyes and body paint. Can bloodroot still be found growing in the city? A. Yes, but it is rare, and can be found in only a few out-of-the-way sites. Bloodroot, a member of the poppy family, blooms early in spring, when a snowy blossom
title: F.Y.I.

body: A transit panel approved a complex and heavily criticized plan yesterday to create a new train line between Queens and Manhattan, called the V train, and to truncate the G line between Brooklyn and Queens on weekdays so that the new line can be shoehorned onto the crowded tracks. The decision had been put off for several weeks as Gov. George E.
title: Panel Approves New V Train but Shortens G Line to Make Room

body: Riding a bicycle to Pennsylvania Station is easy. But what do you do once you get there? The Long Island Rail Road and New Jersey Transit forbid bikes during peak hours, and there are few safe places to lock a bike outside. Transportation Alternatives, a nonprofit advocacy group, has been searching for a space at the station for a secure bike port.
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDTOWN; Pardon Me Boy, Is That Pennsylvania Station's Bike Rack?

body: A 50-acre piece of land in East New York that is being developed into the Gateway Center shopping mall has had some good news to report lately, and it is not just that the long-dormant site has finally been cleared of its chin-high weeds. The property near Starrett City in Brooklyn is expected to house one of the largest suburban-style shopping
title: Commercial Real Estate; A Mall Planned for East New York Is 88% Leased

body: ONE afternoon last summer I was sauntering home with a bag of vegetables when I saw something on my Brooklyn street corner that stopped me in my tracks: a red double-decker sightseeing bus and a throng of sunburned, backpack-toting tourists, chattering excitedly in some Scandinavian language. Cameras flashed and whirred. What was this all about?
title: FRUGAL TRAVELER; Playing Tourist at Home in Brooklyn

body: DENIS O'HARE is a killing machine. At least that is how the casting directors on ''Law and Order'' like to think of him. A veteran New York stage actor, Mr. O'Hare has portrayed not one, not two, not three, but four murderers over the years on this prime-time drama and its sister NBC series, ''Law and Order: Special Victims Unit.'' ''I've gotten
title: On TV, Crime Will Pay

body: ''Be sure you're on the right track.'' So say Metropolitan Transit Authority posters plastered on trains around the city. But many angry G and F train riders in Brooklyn and Queens think the agency has not followed its own advice. These riders are furious over proposed route changes in an M.T.A. plan. The outcry has been so great that the authority
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UNDERGROUND; Reroute the F and G Trains? Derail the Plan, Riders Say

body: It is nearly noon, prime time for unloading garbage at the BFI waste transfer station in the South Bronx. City sanitation trucks back into a cavernous warehouse and dump their loads onto the concrete floor. Bulldozers rumble across, pushing trash toward a 20-foot high mountain of garbage. Soon it will be compacted, loaded onto trucks, and driven to
title: As Garbage Piles Up, So Do Complaints

body: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract. body: Quartet's Final Bow at College The spring concert series at Sarah Lawrence College, which has featured female composers and the music and dance of Bali, will continue next month with a tribute to contemporary European composers (May 6) and dance and music from the Court of Louis XIV (May 11). Despite this varied palette, there was audible
title: Footlights

body: RABER-John W., 89. Predeceased by wives Harriet Neuroth Raber and Marjorie Hein Raber. Father of Phyllis Collett and Douglas. Grandfather of five and greatgrandfather of four. Former President and CEO of the Green Point Savings Bank. Memorial service April 16, 11 AM, Christ Episcopal Church, Ponte Vedra, FL. In lieu of flowers, the family requests
title: Paid Notice: Deaths RABER, JOHN W.

body: BUCKLEY-Reverend Joseph F. On Mar. 19, 2001. Devoted brother of Anne Mullady. Reposing at St. Cecilia's Chapel, 84 Herbert St, Brooklyn on Tuesday 7 to 9PM and on Wednesday 2 to 5PM. Mass of Transferral 7:30PM at St. Cecilia's Church, Greenpoint. Funeral Mass 10:30AM Thursday, March 22 at St. Cecilia's R.C. Church. Interment St. John's Cemetery,
title: Paid Notice: Deaths BUCKLEY, REVEREND JOSEPH F.

body: A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. *

body: YOU start off as a teenager, writing your name on the inside of subway cars, and then one day you're 45, with a wife and two kids. What kind of home do you make for yourself? On a sunny afternoon last week, Lenny McGurr surveyed his duplex apartment in the Greenpoint neighborhood of Brooklyn. Mr. McGurr has been many things: graphic designer,
title: AT HOME WITH/FUTURA; For a King of Krylon, the Family Reigns

body: Alex Winter's ''Fever,'' a somber, paranoid thriller set in New York's outer-borough bohemia, tracks the psychological unraveling of a young artist and drawing instructor named Nick Parker (Henry Thomas), who lives in a run-down tenement in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. The murder of his landlord sets off a chain of troubling events, some of which seem to
title: FILM REVIEW; First, a Murder, and Then Everything Goes Downhill

body: Alfred A. Allegretti, who transformed his father's one-truck oil dealership beside the Gowanus Canal into one of the largest heating oil companies in the New York metropolitan area, died Jan. 13 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 65 and lived in the Bay Ridge neighborhood of Brooklyn. The cause was prostate cancer, his
title: Alfred Allegretti, 65, Heating Oil Executive

body: An arsonist set fire to the front hallway and staircase of a small Brooklyn apartment building early yesterday morning, killing two men who were overcome when smoke billowed through the halls, officials said. Firefighters responding to the alarm around 6 a.m. found the victims, identified as Shawn Price, 32, and Robert Hunter, 24, inside their
title: Brooklyn Arson Kills Two Men

body: PARIS has its Eiffel Tower. Pisa has one, but of course it leans. And New York? It has towers, too. Here, they hold water. The barrel-chested water tank, iron-cinched and balanced on its spindly platform, is a landmark so common, said one architectural historian, Jacob Tilove, that it doesn't need landmarking. After more than a century of stalwart
title: The Humble Colossi Of a Proud Cityscape
